Award.AwardTitle: RI: Small: Collaborative Research: An accelerated numerical solver framework for simulation of solid-fluid dynamics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Modeling and simulation of complex fluids, or intricate systems involving interaction of solid and fluid phases are highly relevant to industrial and engineering applications, and also provides a valuable tool in disciplines such as the study of biofluids and the functional modeling of the circulatory system. The challenges of this task are accentuated by the complexity of the governing physical laws, the demands for accuracy of discrete approximations and the need to accommodate the high resolutions mandated by common applications. Modern hardware offers a unique opportunity: as computational capacity continues to increase, simulations that would have taken days now have the potential of being completed within minutes. However, capitalizing on this potential necessitates a concerted effort of algorithmic development and theoretical innovations in numerics and discretization techniques that promote regularity and expose parallelization opportunities. Alleviating resolution limitations will enable revolutionary new uses of simulation. A promising possibility is the use of simulation in real-time decision making and control. Several ground breaking studies utilize control of solid/fluid interaction but they are limited to linear equations (low Reynolds number flows where Green's functions can be efficiently used). However, the more general nonlinear cases, for example higher Reynolds number Newtonian flows and complex viscoelastic fluids (at all Reynolds numbers) cannot be considered with the tools available in the linear case. This activity will combine expertise from computer engineering, numerical analysis, applied mathematics and experimental physics to jointly address these challenges.

The proposal promotes the potential for scalable parallel performance via the adoption of discretization schemes that leverage regular data structures; in particular it will focus on embedded cut cell methods that couple a Lagrangian representation of the solid with an Eulerian representation of the fluid. It will develop higher order methods that are highly computationally efficient while remaining compatible with linear algebra solvers that are parallel-friendly by design. The key developments will be implicit methodsÂ  specifically designed to accommodate novel parallel multigrid preconditioners for symmetric Krylov solvers. Finally, the modeling approach for the governing equations will be validated against experimental data obtained in Co-PI Kavehpour's research group. The study of complex solid-fluid dynamic interaction can serve as intuitive proving grounds for the development of scalable, parallelism-oriented numerical solvers. Although there are several existing methods in the general field of solid/fluid interactions, there is still considerable room for improvement especially in the case of viscoelastic flows. There is a clear demand for methods that improve accuracy and efficiency. Very few methods achieve higher order accuracy without incurring burdensome computational expense from associated numerical linear algebra. However, bold performance gains require novel algorithms specifically designed for these new architectural specifications. This collaborative activity will engage in cross-cutting interventions to maximize the benefit of computing innovation while striving for an accurate simulation framework validated against experimental findings.

Outreach activities include mentoring underrepresented high school students in scientific computing and large-scale engineering projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Computer simulation of the dynamic behavior in physical systems with interacting sold and fluid components is a highly valuable tool for many industrial and engineering applications. Such simulations are often required to have high accuracy and resolution in order to faithfully reproduce the behavior of real physical media, presenting challenges to computer systems and algorithms alike. Modern computer technology opens the possibility for simulations that years ago would have required weeks or months, to now complete in a matter of days or hours. However, ensuring that this performance potential will materialize in an actual, robust implementation requires a delicate synergy between the process by which discrete equations are crafted to capture the governing laws of a simulated system, the algorithms and data structures that are associated with solving these equations, and the performance optimizations that associated software codes implement to exploit modern computer architectures. Among the challenges associated in crafting such an integrated system are the many possible conflicts among the design traits of the computer simulation; the ability to have increasingly large resolution, the support for complex materials and shapes, the need to use highly accurate governing laws, and the desire to use computer hardware at maximum efficiency are objectives frequently found to be at odds with one another.

This project addressed these challenges by developing a number of innovative techniques, as summarized below:

A crucial challenge was coping with the adverse impact that highly-accurate discrete equations, ones that capture the dynamics of physical systems with high fidelity relative to the resolution devoted to it, often have on the cost of simulation. The complexity of highly accurate discrete formulations, relative to more simplified ones, creates significant variation in the types of computation that need to be performed, reducing the efficacy of parallel computing paradigms that thrive on regularity. Similarly, data structures often become more complicated, and numerical algorithms run a higher risk of unstable performance when coupled with discrete governing laws that optimize for accuracy of representation. We addressed this challenge by demonstrating how such accuracy-oriented equations can be accommodated with collections of simple, performance-optimized data structures, where the necessary interventions for boosting the accuracy are both localized, and injected into the computation in a way that does not dominate the cost. We provided the opportunity for simulations that enjoy high accuracy to also selectively dedicate resolution to diffent locations in space where intricate behavior is taking place, and designed algorithms such that this selective allocation of resources does not adversely impact the regularity of the computation, or its affinity towards modern parallel microprocessors.

Modern hardware has afforded computational science with substantial leaps in efficiency, cost, and resolution. However, those hardware platforms that pack the highest density of computational power for a given price and energy consumption are, almost invariably, heterogeneous computing platforms. A standard example is found in computing servers that pair their main microprocessor (CPU) with a number of Graphics Processing Units (GPUs); the two components have memories with different size and speed, and need to pay a significant overhead to move data between them compared to moving it within a single subsystem. Even commodity processors are becoming increasingly heterogeneous by themselves, as hierarchies of fast/slow memories, multiple computational cores and integrated graphics circuits create a situation where access to data, as well as computation does not have a uniform cost across the entire platform. In this project we identified several opportunities where the performance obstacle incurred by such platform heterogeneity can be circumvented, and the resulting algorithm be made to exhibit competitive performance to a hypothetical system where the aggregate features of all heterogeneous components would be homogeneously available across the entire platform. We exploited this capability in highly detailed simulations of gaseous and liquid media.

Finally, the emerging popularity of the Material Point Method (MPM), a technique that uses coupled particle/grid representations of simulated systems and accommodates a broad spectrum of physical systems with delicate couping aspects, has brought into question what the performance penalty might be that we trade for the convenience and expressive ability that this method offers. We identified challenges where joint use of MPM schemes with either adaptive simulation resolution, intricate geometric shapes occupied by the simulated media (generating sparse occupancy patterns in space), and the convergence of numerial algorithms associated with them, was presenting an obstacle to their adoption. To this end, this project developed efficient hybrids of MPM techniques with adaptive discretizations, as well as demonstrated that performance of such simulation pipelines can be made highly competitive to alternative techniques that either forego adaptivity, accuracy, or flexibility to support various materials.
